keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump announced the end of all US payments and subsidies to Colombia, citing concerns over drug production and accusing President Gustavo Petro of failing to address drug trafficking.
The US has historically provided billions of dollars in annual security and agricultural support to Colombia, with about $210 million in fiscal year assistance and $31 million in agricultural aid.
Colombia is the world’s leading producer of cocaine, accounting for nearly two-thirds of global production according to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime.

The US conducted multiple military strikes in the Caribbean targeting vessels suspected of carrying narcotics, including one in which all three men aboard were killed and another where survivors were returned to Colombia and Ecuador.

Trump accused Petro of being an 'illegal drug leader' and criticized his leadership, while Petro responded by invoking Gabriel García Márquez and criticizing US policies on oil, drug trafficking, and human rights.

The conflict between Trump and Petro intensified over migration, drug trafficking, and diplomatic issues, including the revocation of Petro’s visa and allegations of US military actions killing civilians.
The financial and diplomatic implications of ending US subsidies to Colombia represent a significant shift in US foreign policy toward a key ally in South America.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump announced on October 19, 2025, that he would end all US payments and subsidies to Colombia, accusing President Gustavo Petro of failing to suppress drug production despite years of financial support. The move escalates a long-standing diplomatic and security conflict between the two leaders, rooted in disputes over drug trafficking, migration, and military strikes in the Caribbean. The US has historically provided billions of dollars in aid, including $210 million this fiscal year, with Colombia being the world’s leading producer of cocaine. Recent strikes on alleged drug boats, including one resulting in the deaths of all on board and another with survivors returned, have intensified tensions. Petro responded with cultural and ideological criticism, invoking Nobel laureate Gabriel García Márquez to highlight US ignorance of Colombian society. The episode marks a significant shift in US foreign policy toward Colombia, with financial and military actions reflecting a deepening crisis in transnational drug control and diplomatic relations.
title: Trump escalates back-and-forth with Colombia’s president, announcing end of US payments to country
